author: vors
body:
## Steps to reproduce

From bash run

```
> powershell -NonInteractive
```
## Expected behavior

PowerShell starts, shows logo and finishes, you are back to bash
## Actual behavior

PowerShell process continue to run
## Environment data

``` powershell
> $PSVersionTable

----                           -----
```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: I'm not sure if this is the intended behavior @vors. The ConsoleHost tests combine `-noninteractive` with the `-file` and `-command` flags, and all the tests are passing in #1246. But even then, just running `powershell -noninteractive` drops into a shell. @lzybkr what's the intended behavior if given `-noninteractive` as the only argument?

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
`-noninteractive` isn't really meant to be by itself, it's there so if you run a script that might prompt, we don't actually prompt, e.g. to confirm you really want to kill a process or delete a file or whatever.

I could close this as "won't fix", or possibly "by design" if there is a good example of the existing behavior might be useful, I certainly don't see the expected behavior as useful, why bother running powershell if you don't want it to do anything?

title: Core powershell host doesn't respect -NonInteractive
